instructions: Please answer the following scenario-based questions honestly. Choose the option that best reflects your interests or likely actions. There are no right or wrong answers.

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your school is hosting an annual cultural festival with music, art, and drama. Which role would you volunteer for?

options.A: Designing and creating the stage backdrop and decorations (Creative).

options.B: Performing in a musical or dance act on stage (Performing).

options.C: Writing scripts or content for the event program (Literary).

options.D: Coordinating schedules, logistics, and managing the event (Organizing).

questions.questionText: Scenario: In your English class, you can choose a final project. Which one appeals to you most?

options.A: Write an original short story or poem and present it (Creative Writing).

options.B: Analyze a famous literary work and share your insights (Analytical).

options.C: Perform a scene from a play or recite a poem dramatically (Performing).

options.D: Create artwork or illustrations that depict themes from the literature (Artistic).

questions.questionText: Scenario: For a history project, your group can present the topic in different ways. Which approach would you choose?

options.A: Compile data and timelines into charts and figures (Analytical).

options.B: Dramatize a historical event with costumes and acting (Creative).

options.C: Create a detailed poster or model depicting the era (Artistic).

options.D: Write a first-person diary from a historical figure's perspective (Empathy).

questions.questionText: Scenario: During a family vacation, you have time for one extra activity. Which would you pick?

options.A: Visit an art gallery or handicraft fair to see creative works.

options.B: Attend a live music, dance, or theater performance.

options.C: Explore a historical monument or museum.

options.D: Go to a science and technology museum or planetarium.

questions.questionText: Scenario: On a free Sunday, how are you most likely to spend your time?

options.A: Drawing, painting, or doing DIY art/craft projects.

options.B: Reading a novel, writing in my journal, or composing a poem.

options.C: Listening to music or practicing a musical instrument.

options.D: Solving puzzles, playing chess or video games, or watching science videos.

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your close friend is feeling upset and stressed about a personal issue. How do you help them?

options.A: Write them a heartfelt note or a poem to cheer them up.

options.B: Take them out to do something fun like watch a movie or play music together.

options.C: Sit down and discuss the problem logically to find a solution.

options.D: Offer to simply listen and be there for them without pushing advice.

questions.questionText: Scenario: In art class, your teacher says you can create anything you like for a project. How do you react?

options.A: I get excited and immediately start brainstorming a unique idea.

options.B: I feel a bit unsure and would prefer some guidelines to follow.

options.C: I look for inspiration from famous artworks or cultural themes.

options.D: I discuss ideas with friends to decide on something together.

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your school requires you to join an extracurricular club. Which one do you choose?

options.A: Theater or drama club to act and perform on stage.

options.B: Art and craft club to work on paintings and designs.

options.C: Literary club to discuss books and write stories or poems.

options.D: Science or robotics club to build and experiment.

options.E: Community service club to plan charity events and help others.

questions.questionText: Scenario: You are doing a group project with classmates. What role do you naturally take?

options.A: Coming up with original ideas and designing the project output.

options.B: Leading the team, coordinating everyone's tasks and motivating others.

options.C: Researching the topic thoroughly and providing facts and references.

options.D: Writing and editing the content or presentation script.

options.E: Managing the time schedule and making sure everything stays organized.

questions.questionText: Scenario: Which school event or activity do you look forward to the most?

options.A: The art exhibitions or craft fairs.

options.B: The annual music, dance, or drama performances.

options.C: Debates, literature festivals, or poetry competitions.

options.D: The science fair or math Olympiad.

questions.questionText: Scenario: During a class discussion or project meeting, what kind of contribution do you usually make?

options.A: I suggest creative ideas or unique perspectives that others might not think of.

options.B: I provide logical arguments, facts, or data to support points.

options.C: I draw connections to historical events, books, or examples from culture.

options.D: I make sure everyone gets a chance to speak and help mediate differences.

questions.questionText: Scenario: You need to create a presentation or report for class. What approach do you take?

options.A: Turn it into a story or creative narrative to make it interesting.

options.B: Stick to facts and organize it in a clear, logical structure.

options.C: Include visuals, artwork or even a short performance to engage the audience.

options.D: Emphasize the real-world impact or human aspect of the topic.

questions.questionText: Scenario: Which of the following ways do you most enjoy expressing yourself?

options.A: Through visual art like drawing, painting, or photography.

options.B: Through performing arts like singing, dancing, or acting.

options.C: Through writing stories, poems, or keeping a diary.

options.D: Through solving problems, puzzles, or building things.

questions.questionText: Scenario: When faced with a complex problem or challenge, what do you do first?

options.A: Brainstorm imaginative or unconventional solutions.

options.B: Consider how the people involved feel and what they need.

options.C: Research if similar issues happened before or look up background information.

options.D: Break the problem into parts and tackle it step by step logically.

questions.questionText: Scenario: If you could choose an elective subject to add to your studies, which would it be?

options.A: Fine Arts (e.g., painting, sculpture, design).

options.B: Theatre, Music or Dance (Performing Arts).

options.C: Creative Writing or Journalism.

options.D: Computer Science or Advanced Math.

questions.questionText: Scenario: You are in charge of decorating a room for a school event. How would you approach it?

options.A: Come up with a creative theme and make handmade decorations.

options.B: Incorporate elements that reflect a cultural or historical theme.

options.C: Arrange the space to make sure people feel comfortable and welcomed.

options.D: Organize everything neatly and focus on practical setup (seating, equipment, etc.).

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your school is publishing a magazine. Which task would you volunteer for?

options.A: Designing the cover page and overall layout.

options.B: Writing articles, stories or poems for it.

options.C: Interviewing students and teachers for interesting stories.

options.D: Proofreading all the content and checking facts.

options.E: Coordinating the team and managing deadlines for submissions.

questions.questionText: Scenario: A local cultural festival is looking for student volunteers. What would you most likely do?

options.A: Perform a dance, song or drama piece representing our culture.

options.B: Create art, posters or decorations for the event.

options.C: Take photographs or make a video documentary of the event.

options.D: Help organize the event schedule and coordinate with participants.

options.E: Guide visitors and explain the cultural significance of exhibits.

questions.questionText: Scenario: If you could spend a day shadowing a professional at work, who would you choose?

options.A: A renowned artist or designer, working in their studio.

options.B: A famous musician, dancer or actor rehearsing for a performance.

options.C: An author, journalist or language professor working with literature.

options.D: A historian or museum curator researching and preserving artifacts.

options.E: A scientist or engineer conducting experiments.

questions.questionText: Scenario: When learning about a new topic, what method excites you the most?

options.A: Drawing diagrams, mind maps or visualizing the information.

options.B: Discussing it in a group or acting it out in a role-play.

options.C: Reading books or articles to dive deep into the subject.

options.D: Doing practical experiments or solving problems related to it.

questions.questionText: Scenario: If you had to compete in a school competition, which one would you choose?

options.A: An art or design competition (painting, sketching, etc.).

options.B: A music, dance, or drama contest.

options.C: A debate or public speaking competition.

options.D: A science, math, or technology competition.

questions.questionText: Scenario: When watching a movie or play, what fascinates you the most?

options.A: The visuals, cinematography, and artistic scenes.

options.B: The characters and emotional storylines.

options.C: The deeper message, theme or historical setting.

options.D: The special effects, sound design, or technical aspects.

questions.questionText: Scenario: You have some free time at the school library. Which section do you browse first?

options.A: Fiction and literature – novels, stories, poetry.

options.B: Art and photography – books full of images and drawings.

options.C: History and culture – biographies, history books, social studies.

options.D: Science and technology – science magazines, how-things-work books.

options.E: Psychology and self-improvement – books about people and mind.

questions.questionText: Which statement sounds the most like you?

options.A: I constantly have new ideas and imaginative stories or art in my head.

options.B: I often think about other people’s feelings and want to understand them.

options.C: I love learning about different cultures, histories, and ideas.

options.D: I enjoy brainteasers, riddles, or solving tricky problems.

questions.questionText: Scenario: You are looking at an abstract painting in an art gallery. What are you most likely thinking or doing?

options.A: Imagining what the painting represents and coming up with my own story for it.

options.B: Appreciating the colors, shapes, and how it makes me feel without needing a clear meaning.

options.C: Talking with a friend about what the artist might be trying to say or convey.

options.D: Reading the description or researching the artist to understand the context.

questions.questionText: Scenario: When you think about your future career, what matters most to you?

options.A: Having the freedom to be creative and express myself.

options.B: Helping others and making a positive impact on people’s lives.

options.C: Constantly learning and exploring ideas, history, or culture.

options.D: Achieving financial stability and a secure life.

questions.questionText: Scenario: Imagine you open a magazine with different sections. Which section do you go to first?

options.A: The word puzzles section (crosswords, word games).

options.B: The number puzzles section (like Sudoku or brain teasers).

options.C: The spot-the-difference or comic/art page.

options.D: The advice column or personality quiz page.

questions.questionText: Scenario: You have to perform or speak in front of a large audience. How do you feel about it?

options.A: Very comfortable – I enjoy being on stage and engaging the audience.

options.B: Somewhat comfortable – I can manage but I prefer smaller groups.

options.C: Not very comfortable – I get quite nervous speaking or performing in public.

options.D: I would avoid it if possible – being in front of a crowd isn’t for me.

questions.questionText: Scenario: When working on any project or assignment, what is your top priority?

options.A: That it’s creative and visually appealing.

options.B: That it’s well-researched and informative.

options.C: That it’s finished on time and meets all requirements.

options.D: That it has a personal touch and meaning to me.

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your school is hosting an exhibition where each student presents a project of their choice. What do you choose to do?

options.A: Conduct a science experiment or build a gadget to display.

options.B: Prepare a research poster or presentation on a historical or social topic.

options.C: Create an original artwork or craft to showcase.

options.D: Perform a short play, music piece, or dance at the exhibition.

questions.questionText: Scenario: It’s your birthday and you got some extra money as a gift. What would you most likely spend it on?

options.A: New art supplies, a musical instrument, or something creative.

options.B: Books, museum tickets, or an educational course.

options.C: Tickets to a concert, theater show, or art film festival.

options.D: A new gadget, video game, or science kit.

questions.questionText: Scenario: Your friends often praise you for:

options.A: Your creativity and imaginative ideas.

options.B: Your empathy and ability to understand them.

options.C: Your knowledge and interesting facts or stories you share.

options.D: Your practicality and problem-solving skills.

questions.questionText: Scenario: Which type of news or articles are you most drawn to?

options.A: Arts and entertainment news (films, music, art shows).

options.B: Human interest stories or social issues.

options.C: Global news, history, or cultural articles.

options.D: Science and technology updates.

questions.questionText: Scenario: A friend is struggling to understand a difficult lesson. How would you help them learn it?

options.A: Break it down into simple, logical steps with examples.

options.B: Create a fun analogy, drawing or demo to explain the idea.

options.C: Relate it to something in real life or how it might affect people.

options.D: Find a good reference book or online resource that explains it well.

questions.questionText: Scenario: You have a really unusual, creative idea for a project, but you’re not sure how it will be received. What do you do?

options.A: Go for it fully – I love taking creative risks and trying new ideas.

options.B: Try it out but keep a backup plan in case it doesn’t work.

options.C: Tone it down to be more in line with what’s expected.

options.D: Decide not to take the risk and stick with a safer approach.

questions.questionText: Scenario: What kind of work environment do you think you'd thrive in?

options.A: A bustling studio or office with lots of people and constant creative collaboration.

options.B: A quiet, private space like a library or art studio to work on my own ideas.

options.C: A structured office environment with clear routines and tasks.

options.D: Out in the field, meeting people and doing something different every day.

questions.questionText: Scenario: If you could change one thing in the world for the better, what would it be?

options.A: I would make sure everyone has more opportunities to experience art and creativity.

options.B: I would foster greater empathy and understanding among people.

options.C: I would preserve cultural heritage and encourage people to learn about history.

options.D: I would advance science and technology to improve lives.

questions.questionText: Scenario: When you're browsing online or on your phone, what content do you spend the most time on?

options.A: Watching art, DIY, or creative videos (like painting, music, crafts).

options.B: Scrolling through social media, interacting with friends or following inspiring stories.

options.C: Reading articles or watching documentaries about history, culture, or ideas.

options.D: Watching science, tech, or how-to videos and solving quizzes/games.

questions.questionText: Scenario: Think about your school classes. Which subject do you enjoy the most?

options.A: Languages or Literature (like English, Hindi, etc.)

options.B: Art, Music or Drama class.

options.C: Social Studies (History, Geography, Economics).

options.D: Mathematics or Science.

questions.questionText: Scenario: Imagine yourself 10 years from now, successful and happy. Which scene do you picture?

options.A: I am in a creative field, like an artist, designer, writer, or filmmaker, creating something new.

options.B: I am in a role where I work closely with people or communities, making a difference in their lives.

options.C: I am an academic or expert, immersed in research, culture, or education (like a professor or historian).

options.D: I am in a technical or corporate field, solving problems or managing projects in a big organization.
